text: , also known as Mei-ō, was a after Entoku and before Bunki. This period started in July 1492 and ended in February 1501.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Mei-ō" in Japan encyclopedia, p. 625. During this time, the emperors were Nussbaum, "Go-Tsuchimikado Tennō," p. 265. and .Nussbaum, "Go-Kashiwabara Tennō," p. 255;Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du Japon, pp. 352-364. == Events of the Meiō era == * 1492 (Meiō 1, 8th month): Shogun Ashikaga YoshimuraTitsingh, p. 364; the son of Shogun Yoshimi was named Yoshimura until 1501 when he changed his name to Yoshitane. led an army into Ōmi Province.Titsingh, p. 362. * 1492 (Meiō 2, 1st month): The kampaku Ichijō Fuyuyoshi was named daijō-daijin. * 1492 (Meiō 2, 2nd month): Shogun Yoshimura led an army against the daimyo of Kawachi Province. * 1495 (Meiō 4): Statue of Kannon carved in the 8th century was lost to fire at Hase-dera in Nara.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Hase-dera" in Japan Encyclopedia, pp. 291-292; Washizuka, Hiromitsu. (1997). Enlightenment embodied: the art of the Japanese Buddhist sculptor, p. 55. * 12 September 1495 (Meiō 4, 24th day of the 8th month): Earthquake at Kashima (Latitude: 35.100/Longitude: 139.500), 7.1 magnitude on the Richter Scale.National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Geophysical Data Center (NGDC): NOAA/Japan: Significant Earthquake Database; retrieved 2011-12-3. * 9 July 1498 (Meiō 7, 20th day of the 6th month): Earthquake in the Enshunada Sea (Latitude: 34.400/Longitude: 137.700), 6.4 on the Richter Scale. * 20 September 1498 (Meiō 7, 2nd day of the 7th month): Earthquake in the Enshunada Sea (Latitude: 34.000/Longitude: 138.100), 8.6 on the Richter Scale; and also on that same day, another earthquake in Nankaido (Latitude: 33.500/Longitude: 135.200), 7.5 on the Richter Scale. * 21 October 1500 (Meiō 9, 28th day of the 9th month): Emperor Go-Tuschimikado died.Titsingh, p. 363-364; Imperial Household Agency (Kunaichō): 後土御門天皇 (103); retrieved 2012-5-23. ==Related pages== * Muromachi period == References == == Other websites == * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Meiō 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th 7th 8th 9th 10th 1492 1493 1494 1495 1496 1497 1498 1499 1500 1501 Preceded by: Entoku Era or nengō: Meiō Succeeded by: Bunki Category:Japanese eras
title: Meiō
